page.lettertext:
fol.276r
Belgia
1591 20 Novem
b
To my L. Trea
s
Belgia
May it please yo
r
L. to advertise her Ma
tie
at
after
e receat of her Hig
nes
letter of
e 9 of this
moneth, w
ch
was delivered unto me
e 18 day
in
e afternoone, after c
o
fer
e
ce had w
t
S
r
Francis
Vere, about
e meanes to acc
o
plishe her Ma
ties
pleasure, for
e further
a
ce wherof he hath done
his uttermost endevo
r
,
e next day in
e mor-
ning I pres
e
ted her letters to suche of Holland
as are deputed in
e absence of
e states, to receave
all addresses. For
e assembly it self of
e Gene-
ral states is dissolved for a time, w
ch
they terme
a Recesse, till
e 10 of Dec
e
ber, and every
Deputy
de
ted
to his special Province, leaving
e charge of receav
i
g
and open
i
g of suche letters, as are directed to the
states to some certaine of Holland, whose autoritie
doth not stretche to determine any mater, but onely
to advertise and to make report unto
e Prov
i
ces.
Nevertheles in this recesse of
e states being ear-
nestly urged to shew her Ma
ties
letters to
e Councel
of state and to joine in c
o
sultati
o
about some
order to be taken for c
o
tenting of her Hig
nes
they
assembled yesternight in
e college of
e Councel
where
e letter being read, and so muche added
by me, as I thought expedient to be spoken, it
was
e opini
o
of them all,
at w
t
out
e assent of
their superio
rs
, to witte of
e Prov
i
ces, it was
not in their power to accorde her Ma
ties
demaund,
Howbeit after long debating too and fro, it was
resolved in
e end, but w
t
very muche a doe,
that albeit they might not by any meanes
licence these troupes w
ch
her Hig
nes
required to
be drawen from hens, for
at it onely bel
o
ged
to
e generallitie of
e c
o
try, yet they would
be c
o
tented to lett them passe by way of
c
o
nivati
o
and suffer
a
ce
as if it were onely done by us
that are heer for her Ma
tie
But this c
o
diti
o
was a
n
exed,
at I should solemnely undertake
that
e troupes should be sent backe againe
w
t
in
e space of 3 monethes. This c
o
diti
o
, I
signified, was beyonde any charge
at I had
receaved onely this I was willed to
mise unto
fol.276v
Belgia: 1591: No
v
them, and in her Ma
ties
behalf I would assure
that assoone as
e service of Rouen and Newe
haven is ended w
ch
in all
babilitie will be
done in lesse
time
then
time
they had p
r
scribed, ether
e
self same c
o
panies, or others in their places shall
be presently returned. As also I supposed
at
those other Englishe forces, w
ch
were already
come to Rouen, would all be revoked about
a time, whereby they should receave these c
o
panies againe w
t
a rounde renforcem
t
, and
happely also some supplie for all
e rest
at
are heere in her Ma
ties
pay. Wherupon they
condescended to her Ma
ties
desire
request. And
this I thought meete w
t
all possible speede
to advertise her Hig
nes
purpos
ing
presently
to joine w
t
S
r
Francis Vere for giving suche
dir
directi
o
to
e Commissary Sparhawke
as there may not any time be lost for dis-
patche of
e souldiers. In this whole negotiation
although her Ma
tie
had willed me, in case they
should refuse to assent to her demaund, that
all endevo
r
should be used to effect it w
t
out
them, yet because I was not forced to signifie
so muche, finding them ready to doe all
that they cowld, I abstened fr
o
deliver
i
g
that point of my charge. Moreover
I made no moti
o
unto them for sending
any bandes of their owne forces, for that
of themselves I knowe they will not, and
if they would, they can not, w
t
out
e licence
of their Principals. Howbeyt for shipping
for
e river of Sene,
e Mareschal of Biron
hath written very often and earnestly unto
them, and they have already alotted
6 good shippes for
at purpose, w
ch
I thinke
are p
r
pared to sett forward to day. If
her
Ma
tie
be desirous, to have these c
o
panies
complete
that goe fr
o
hens, it will be requisit
that
some 100 or more, be sent out of England
to Dieppe
For
heere
I see no likelihoode,
heere
howe it c
a
be
[.]
And thus I take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hage N
o
20 1591.
